title: 115_hr3017
content: The Act is titled the "Brownfields Enhancement, Economic Redevelopment, and Reauthorization Act of 2017." It amends a section of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 regarding ownership or control by governmental entities. Additionally, it includes provisions for petroleum brownfield enhancement. SEC. 3. PETROLEUM BROWNFIELD ENHANCEMENT. Amends the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 regarding sites without a responsible party for assessment, investigation, or cleanup by a non-liable entity. SEC. 4. CLARIFICATION OF LEASEHOLDER INTEREST. Section 101(40) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to include provisions for individuals acquiring ownership or leasehold interest in a facility. The Administrator will establish standards for those acquiring a leasehold interest in a facility. The amendment includes provisions for individuals acquiring a leasehold interest in a facility for a term of at least 5 years, granting control and access to the facility. The amendment requires that individuals acquiring a leasehold interest in a facility for at least 5 years must be responsible for managing all hazardous substances at the facility. SEC. 5. EXPANDED ELIGIBILITY FOR NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS. Expanded eligibility for nonprofit organizations under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 includes organizations described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and limited liability corporations with managing members or sole members meeting the same criteria. Expanded eligibility under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 now includes limited partnerships with general partners meeting specific criteria and qualified community development entities. Amendments to Section 104(k) involve removing references to nonprofit organizations in certain subparagraphs. Amendments to Section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 expand eligibility to include limited partnerships with qualified general partners and eligible entities. This involves removing references to nonprofit organizations in specific subparagraphs. SEC. 6. Treatment of publicly owned brownfield sites. Section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to provide an exemption for certain publicly owned brownfield sites, allowing eligible entities to receive grants for property acquired before January 11, 2002, even if they do not qualify as bona fide prospective purchasers, as long as they have not caused or contributed to hazardous substance releases. The amendment to Section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 provides an exemption for certain publicly owned brownfield sites, allowing eligible entities to receive grants or loans for property acquired before January 11, 2002, even if they do not qualify as bona fide prospective purchasers, as long as they have not caused or contributed to hazardous substance releases. The amendment allows eligible entities to receive grants or loans for brownfield sites acquired before January 11, 2002, by inserting specific criteria after "eligible entities". SEC. 7 amends the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act to increase the remediation grant limit to $500,000 per site, with a maximum of $750,000 based on contamination level, size, or ownership status. SEC. 8 introduces multipurpose brownfields grants. Section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to establish a program for multipurpose brownfields grants to eligible entities for inventory and characterization. The program for multipurpose brownfields grants allows eligible entities to receive grants up to $1,000,000 for activities at brownfield sites, with a total limit of 15% of the funds available for the fiscal year. The Administrator considers specific criteria when awarding grants. The Administrator considers various criteria for eligible entities to receive multipurpose brownfields grants, including providing a revitalization plan, demonstrating capacity for funded activities, and meeting the needs of brownfield sites. Grant recipients must fully expend the grant amount within a specified timeframe. The grant recipient must spend the full grant amount within 5 years of receiving it, unless an extension is granted. The entity cannot use the funds for brownfield site remediation until they own the site. SEC. 9. ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS FOR GRANT RECIPIENTS. SEC. 9. ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS FOR GRANT RECIPIENTS. Paragraph (5) of section 104(k) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to address administrative costs. An eligible entity can use up to 5% of grant or loan amounts for administrative costs, excluding investigation, design, response actions, and natural resource monitoring. SEC. 10 amends the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act to include consideration of renewable energy production on brownfield sites. SEC. 11 establishes small community technical assistance grants. Section 128(a)(1)(B) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to assist small communities, Indian tribes, rural areas, or disadvantaged areas in carrying out activities with respect to brownfield sites. To support small communities, Indian tribes, rural areas, and disadvantaged areas in addressing brownfield sites, grants may be provided by the Administrator using up to $1,500,000 annually from section 104(k)(7) funds, with each grant not exceeding $20,000. The term 'disadvantaged area' refers to a community with a household income less than 2/3 of the statewide median income, while 'small community' is defined as having a population of not more than 10,000 individuals. Section 104(g)(1) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended to include a new provision. SEC. 12. BROWNFIELDS FUNDING and SEC. 13. STATE RESPONSE PROGRAM FUNDING authorize appropriations of $200,000,000 and $50,000,000 respectively for fiscal years 2018 through 2022 under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
